item.title: Japan Says No US Demand for Defense Spending Worth 3.5% of GDP
item.description: Japan denied a report that the US directly asked Tokyo to raise its defense spending to 3.5% of annual gross domestic product, with its top government spokesman saying that the amount of spending was less important than how Japan raises its military capabilities.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Sarah Hilton

media:content.media:description: The Japan Self Defense Forces. Photographer: Keith Bedford/Bloomberg

item.title: What Turning a Blind Eye to Deviant Behavior Is Doing to London
item.description: The city’s mayor, Sadiq Khan, needs to take growing disorder on the streets more seriously.
item.dc:creator: Adrian Wooldridge

media:content.media:description: Graffiti covers part of a train carriage on the Bakerloo Line on June 16, 2025, in London, England.

item.title: Britain's HS2 Is Frankenstein's Railway
item.description: How a high-speed rail project became a fiscal monster.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Brooker

media:content.media:description: An aerial view the HS2 Curzon No.2 Viaduct on June 18, 2025, in Birmingham, England.

item.title: Thai Leader Defies Calls to Quit as Border Spat Escalates
item.description: Thai leader Paetongtarn Shinawatra looks poised to brazen out a political crisis engulfing her government, with a cabinet expansion to keep her coalition intact and a tougher stance in a simmering border dispute with Cambodia.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

item.title: UBS Downgrades Thai Stocks to Neutral as Political Woes Weigh
item.description: UBS Group AG strategists downgraded Thai stocks to neutral from overweight, citing recent political uncertainty which could impact policy direction and investor sentiment.
item.dc:creator: John Cheng

item.title: Philippine VP Duterte Criticizes Marcos for Leaning Towards US
item.description: Philippine Vice President Sara Duterte slammed President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. for leaning towards the US, while signaling openness to friendlier ties with China.
item.dc:creator: Andreo Calonzo

media:content.media:description: Sara Duterte Photographer: Lisa Marie David/Bloomberg

item.title: IMF’s Georgieva Warns of Broader Risks From US Strikes on Iran
item.description: International Monetary Fund Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva warned that the US strikes on Iran could potentially have broader impacts beyond energy channels, as global uncertainty escalates.
item.dc:creator: Shery Ahn, Yuko Takeo

media:content.media:description: Kristalina Georgieva in Tokyo on June 23.

item.title: A Weakened Iran Can Still Inflict Pain on the US — and the World
item.description: When the dust settled on Iran’s nuclear sites on Sunday after a US bombing raid that President Donald Trump said had “totally obliterated” its atomic program, one thing was still missing: its highly enriched uranium, which international authorities haven't seen for more than a week.
item.dc:creator: Golnar Motevalli, Peter Martin

media:content.media:description: Portraits of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and late leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, as demonstrators protest US strikes on Iran's nuclear facilities, in downtown Tehran on June 22.

item.title: US Strikes Iran in Operation Midnight Hammer
item.description: On today’s Big Take podcast: what’s next for the Israel-Iran war after 14 US “bunker busters.”
item.dc:creator: Sarah Holder, David Fox

media:content.media:description: A B-2 Spirit approaches a KC-135 Stratotanker in 2019. Source: Staff Sgt. Jordan Castelan/U.S. Air Force

item.title: US Issues ‘Worldwide Caution’ for Americans After Attack on Iran
item.description: The US State Department issued a “Worldwide Caution” alert for American citizens, flagging the potential of travel disruptions and demonstrations following the US strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities.
item.dc:creator: Bill Faries

media:content.media:description: Photo by Milos Bicanski/Getty Images) Photographer: Milos Bicanski/Getty Images Europe

item.title: World Braces for Iran’s Response After US Strikes Signal New Era
item.description: The unprecedented US airstrikes on Iran have set traders and governments worldwide on edge, as the Islamic Republic warns of retaliation and Israel shows no sign of letting up in its assault.
item.dc:creator: Ramsey Al-Rikabi

media:content.media:description: Abbas Araghchi Photographer: Fred Merz/Bloomberg

item.title: Farage Promises Non-Doms Protection From Tax on Overseas Assets
item.description: Nigel Farage’s Reform UK party is offering non-doms full exemption from tax on their overseas assets for a fee of £250,000 ($335,000) every 10 years with the revenue redistributed to lower income workers, drawing a new battle line with Britain’s traditional parties.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: Nigel Farage

item.title: Iran Strikes Risk Dividing GOP at Crucial Time for Trump Agenda
item.description: Donald Trump’s unilateral decision to strike Iran’s key nuclear sites on Saturday notably sidelined Congress just as he needs Republicans lawmakers to unite around one thing he can’t do without them: Pass his legislative agenda.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Tarabay, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump addresses the nation in the East Room of the White House in Washington, DC, on June 21.

item.title: Decoy Stealth Bombers and Tomahawk Missiles: How the US Hit Iran
item.description: The heart of operation “Midnight Hammer” was a feint.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio

item.title: Netanyahu Says Iran Nuclear Site Damaged as Full Results Unknown
item.description: The US airstrike on the best-defended Iranian nuclear facility delivered “a great deal of damage,” but the full extent is not yet known, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said.
item.dc:creator: Dan Williams

media:content.media:description: Maxar satellite imagery shows the ridge above the Fordow complex with multiple impact craters following US strikes in Iran on June 22, 2025.

item.title: UN Nuclear Chief Urges Halt to Iran Strikes to Allow Inspections
item.description: The head of the United Nations atomic watchdog called for a return to diplomacy after the US strikes on Iran’s nuclear program, saying there’s “a window of opportunity” to return to dialogue.
item.dc:creator: Magdalena Del Valle

media:content.media:description: Rafael Mariano Grossi, director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), during an interview at the agency's headquarters in Vienna, Austria, on Monday, Feb. 24, 2025. Grossi says more countries are considering whether they need their own deterrent.

item.title: Iran Stands Alone Against Trump and Israel, Stripped of Allies
item.description: Iran’s leaders are discovering they’re on their own against the US and Israel, without the network of proxies and allies that allowed them to project power in the Middle East and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: Iranian demonstrators during a protest following the strikes on Iranian nuclear sites, in Tehran on June 22, 2025.

item.title: Shipping on High Alert in Mideast After US Strikes on Iran
item.description: The shipping industry was placed on high alert on Sunday with warnings that Tehran could retaliate against commercial vessels following US airstrikes against Iran’s nuclear facilities.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley, Viktoria Dendrinou

media:content.media:description: Iranian soldiers take part in the "National Persian Gulf day" in the Strait of Hormuz, on April 30, 2019. - The date coincides with the anniversary of a successful military campaign by Shah Abbas the Great of Persia in the 17th century, which drove the Portuguese navy out of the Hormuz Island, after which is named the waterway which separates the Gulf from the Sea of Oman. (Photo by ATTA KENARE / AFP) (Photo credit should read ATTA KENARE/AFP/Getty Images)

item.title: Spain Wins Exemption From NATO’s 5% Defense Spending Goal
item.description: Spain obtained an exemption from NATO’s ambitious defense spending target of 5% of GDP after several days of diplomatic wrangling that drew scorn from Donald Trump, right before leaders of the military alliance gather on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano, Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: A Spanish Air Force Eurofighter Typhoon fighter jet on the runway during a NATO exercise.

item.title: Satellite Images Question Trump’s Claim Iran’s Atomic Sites Destroyed
item.description: The task of ensuring Iran doesn’t build a weapon might just have got tougher.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone, Rachel Lavin

media:content.media:description: after airstrikes_overview of fordow underground complex — June 22.

item.title: New York to LA Ramp Up Security After US Airstrikes on Iran
item.description: Major US cities are tightening security after President Donald Trump unleashed airstrikes on Iran, a direct military intervention that’s deepened Washington’s role in Israel’s war with Tehran and raised concerns about potential retaliation.
item.dc:creator: Myles Miller

media:content.media:description: ホワイトハウス周辺のラファイエット広場は封鎖された（21日）

item.title: Iran Says ‘All Options’ Open After US Strikes Atomic Sites
item.description: Iran warned there would be consequences for US strikes on its key nuclear sites and said it “reserves all options,” while showing restraint in its initial response.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: Satellite imagery of the Fordow Fuel Enrichment Plant following US strikes in Iran on June 22. Source: Planet LabsPBC

item.title: Ukraine Says Russia Not Winding Down and Now Eyeing Europe
item.description: Russia shows no signs it plans to wind down its war in Ukraine, with an estimated 695,000 troops deployed across an expanded front line and another 121,000 in strategic reserve, according to Ukraine’s commander-in-chief Oleksandr Syrskyi.
item.dc:creator: Olesia Safronova

media:content.media:description: Oleksandr Syrskyi.

item.title: Turkey Arrests Journalist for Threatening Erdogan, NTV Reports
item.description: Turkish authorities arrested a prominent local journalist on charges of threatening President Recep Tayyip Erdogan amid an intensifying crackdown on political opposition.
item.dc:creator: Asli Kandemir

media:content.media:description: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, Turkey's president, during a news conference at Villa Doria Pamphili in Rome, at Villa Doria Pamphili in Roma, Italy, on Tuesday, April 29, 2025. Erdogan travelled to Italy to meet with Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni and attend a business forum in Rome.

item.title: Tanzania Arrests YouTubers as Pre-Election Crackdown Intensifies
item.description: Tanzanian police have arrested two local YouTubers as President Samia Suluhu Hassan’s government steps up a crackdown on dissent ahead of elections.
item.dc:creator: Helen Nyambura

media:content.media:description: Samia Suluhu Hassan, Tanzania's President, during a panel session on day three of the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, on Thursday, Jan. 19, 2023. The annual Davos gathering of political leaders, top executives and celebrities runs from January 16 to 20.

item.title: Senate Can Keep Ban on State AI Rules in Trump Tax Bill
item.description: A Republican effort to block US states from enforcing new artificial intelligence regulations will remain in President Donald Trump’s massive tax and spending package for now, marking a win for tech companies pushing to stall and override dozens of AI safety laws across the country.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington on June 2. Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: Ivory Coast’s Ouattara Delays Decision on Fourth Term Bid
item.description: Ivory Coast President Alassane Ouattara surprised delegates as he shelved his decision to accept the party’s nomination as the presidential candidate for October elections to a later date.
item.dc:creator: Kamailoudini Tagba

media:content.media:description: Alassane Ouattara Photographer: Denis Balibouse/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Trump Stakes His Legacy on Iran Attack
item.description: It remains unclear if this is the end of the military campaign, or whether the confrontation could spiral into a push for regime change in Tehran
item.dc:creator: Peter Martin

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump in The Situation Room on June 21. White House

item.title: The US Has Two Paths in Iran. Tehran’s Clerics Will Decide Both.
item.description: What comes next will show whether they’re more pragmatic than portrayed.
item.dc:creator: Marc Champion

media:content.media:description: A demonstrator holds a sign outside the White House in Washington, on Saturday, June 21, 2025.

item.title: US Strikes Iran’s Nuclear Sites, Risking Wider Mideast War
item.description: The US carried out airstrikes on three nuclear sites in Iran overnight, directly entering Israel’s war with Tehran despite President Donald Trump’s longtime promises to avoid new foreign conflicts.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Akayla Gardner, Arsalan Shahla
